column5: Scopenote

column1: Gregg Home, Shelby County, Kentucky
column5: Gregg home in Shelby County, Kentucky. This was the ancestral home of President Harry S. Truman's maternal relatives. Harriet Louisa Gregg, Truman's maternal grandmother, lived in this home when she married Solomon Young.

column1: Truman and Leahy aboard "The Independence"
column5: Admiral William D. Leahy and President Harry S. Truman study a map while aboard the Presidential airplane, "The Independence."

column1: Broken Exhibit Case for Stolen Swords, at Truman Library
column5: A view of the broken glass in the lobby exhibit case where swords and daggers were stolen from the Harry S. Truman Library. The swords and daggers were gifts from King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317). This photo is in a contact sheet book and is from an original 2x2 negative.

column1: Nancy Tyler Holmes, President Truman's paternal great grandmother
column5: Portrait of Nancy Tyler Holmes, paternal great grandmother of President Truman. Original daguerreotype is under number 72-3468.

column1: Judge Harry S. Truman with Alex Sachs and N. T. Veatch
column5: Jackson County Judge Harry S. Truman (center) with friends and associates Alex Sachs (left) and N. T. Veatch (right) at the Veatch farm.

column1: Senator Truman Speaks at Ground Breaking of Pratt and Whitney Plant in Kansas City
column5: Senator Harry S. Truman is the keynote speaker at the ground breaking ceremony for the Pratt and Whitney Plant in Kansas City. He is shown speaking at the podium, the sky in the background. Pratt and Whitney later became the Bendix Plant, located in Kansas City, Missouri at 95th and Troost. Donor: Harvey H. Lippincott, archivist of Pratt and Whitney. It was sent to the Truman Library by Floyd A. Walker, editor of Bendix newsletter. Credit photo to Pratt and Whitney. The Pratt and Whitney Archives are located in East Hartford, Connecticut.

column1: President Truman and General Marshall
column5: President Harry S. Truman presents General George C. Marshall with a permanent membership in the Reserve Officers Association at a banquet at the Mayflower Hotel, Washington, D.C.

column1: President Harry S. Truman With Medal of Honor Recipient
column5: President Harry S. Truman (center) is shaking hands with U.S. Army Master Sergeant Charles L. McCaha, Cosby, Tennessee, after he presented him the Congressional Medal of Honor for bravery shown during battle at Luzon, Philippine Islands on February 7, 1945.  The event was held on the White House lawn.  Standing to the back left of President Truman is Naval Aide Captain James K. Vardaman and directly behind Truman is Admiral William D. Leahy.  Ceremonies were held on the White House south grounds in order that they may be witnessed by two bus-loads of disabled veterans, who had planned to see the White House grounds from bus.  An African American solder is shown in a wheelchair on the right.

column1: President Harry S. Truman Presents Medal of Honor to Recipient
column5: President Harry S. Truman (center at podium) is shown preparing to present the Congressional Medal of Honor to Commander Richard H. O'Kane, Dover, New Hampshire, for bravery shown as commander of the submarine the USS Tang during battle near the Philippine Islands on October 23-24, 1944. The event was held on the White House lawn. Standing on the left is President Truman's Military Aide Harry Vaughan.  Standing directly behind Truman is Captain James Vardaman, Naval Aide and to his right is Admiral William Leahy. Ceremonies were held on the White House south grounds in order that they may be witnessed by two bus-loads of disabled veterans who had planned to see the White House grounds from bus.

column1: President Truman Aids Famine Relief
column5: Surrounded by members of Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc. (CARE), President Harry S. Truman makes a statement to promote famine relief in Europe in the Rose Garden at the White House. Front row, left to right: Major General Glen Edgerton; President Truman; executive director of CARE, Lt. General William N. Haskell. The men in the back row are not specifically identified, but according to the president's appointment book, Walter A. Joyce and Tom Burland also attended this event.

column1: Bob Mathias with President Harry S. Truman at White House
column5: President Harry S. Truman (center) meets with U. S. Olympic champion, 17 year old decathlon winner Bob Mathias (left). The occasion is the celebration of Youth Month, the month of September. The young man at right is unidentified. From: Atlantic Press.

column1: A group of people standing with President Truman in his private train car
column5: This photo is of a group of mostly African American people standing with President Harry S. Truman in his train car. Left to Right: Press Secretary Charles Ross; Ann Hedgeman; J. McKinley Neal; Robert L. Sweeney; Lewis W. Clymer; and President Truman. The photograph is autographed "Kindest regards to Robert L. Sweeney from Harry S. Truman, October 1948." (Same as 2006-208, only this one is autographed). The caption on the back of the photo reads: "This picture was taken in Pres. Truman's train in his private car, the Ferdinand MaGellan. This was the only group who saw him on this trip. He had spoken in Des Moines, Iowa. The arrangement for this historic occasion were made in my dining room, 2821 Highland...On this date, Mr. Truman was a 100 to 1 shot to win the election, but I knew he would win. I owe everything to President Truman, one of America's greatest Presidents. Robert L. Sweeney." From: Robert L. Sweeney, donated at the time of his oral history interview.

column1: Cartoon by Bill McClanahan "Aw C'mon Mule -- Drink"
column5: Political cartoon by Bill McClanahan entitled "Aw C'mon Mule -- Drink." It shows a mule labeled Southern Democrats being pulled by President Truman to a barrel labeled Fair Deal. Cartoon is by Bill McClanahan for the Dallas Morning News.

column1: Close up of President Truman signing Housing Act
column5: Close-up portrait of President Harry S. Truman as he signed the Housing Act of 1949.

column1: Portrait photograph of Mary Jane Truman
column5: Portrait photograph of Mary Jane Truman, sister of President Harry S. Truman. Photo is an enlargement of 78-101. Taken at an Eastern Star dinner.

column1: Portrait of Eddie Jacobson
column5: Portrait of Eddie Jacobson.  Printed underneath the photo is "Distinguished member of B'Nai B'rith, exemplary citizen, devoted American, and noble Jew."  The photo is autographed along the bottom by Jacobson; most of it is illegible.

column1: Lincoln Bedroom in White House
column5: Lincoln Bedroom of the White House.  Oversize print is in oversize drawer.

column1: President Truman's Bedroom in White House
column5: President Harry S. Truman's bedroom in the White House.  Original print is in oversize drawer.

column1: Blue Room at the White House, Post-Renovation
column5: The Blue Room after renovations at the White House were completed.

column1: Queen's Bedroom in White House
column5: The Queen's Bedroom or the Rose Guest Room of the White House.  Oversize print is in oversize drawer.

column1: Bess Truman's Bedroom in White House
column5: Bess Truman's bedroom in the White House.  Oversize print is in oversize drawer.

column1: Family Dining Room in White House
column5: Family dining room or small state dining room in the White House.  This photo was taken after the renovation.  Original print is in oversize drawer.

column1: White House Red Room
column5: The White House Red Room after the completion of the renovations to the White House.

column1: White House Green Room
column5: The Green Room of the White House, after the renovations were completed.

column1: Margaret Truman's Bedroom in White House
column5: Margaret Truman's bedroom in the White House.  Original oversize print is in oversize drawer.

column1: White House State Dining Room
column5: The White House State Dining Room after renovations in the White House were completed.

column1: President Harry S. Truman With Medal of Honor Recipient
column5: President Harry S. Truman (foreground, left) is congratulating recent Congressional Medal of Honor recipient U.S. Marine Major William E. Barber, West Liberty, Kentucky.  Major Barber received this award for his actions in Korea during the Battle of Chosin Reservoir in 1950.  The award presentation took place in the Rose Garden at the White House.  Family and friends are in view behind President Truman and Major Barber.

column1: President Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower in Oval Office
column5: President Harry S. Truman and President-Elect Dwight D. Eisenhower during their historic conference at the White House.  They are in the Oval Office.  They issued a joint statement hailing the "arrangements we have made for cooperation" during the change of administrations.  Photo from European (purchase).

column1: Former President Truman Walks Outside Independence Home
column5:
Original caption: "Former President Harry Truman, alone and relaxed from the tensions of life in the White House, walks past his home in Independence as he takes an early morning stroll. After seven strenuous years as the nation's Chief Executive, Mr. Truman is enjoying his well-deserved rest."

Former President Harry S. Truman walks along the sidewalk outside the Truman Home at 219 N. Delaware in Independence, Missouri.

column1: Color photo of the Truman family in Hawaii
column5: From left to right: Mrs. Bess Wallace Truman, former President Harry S. Truman, and Margaret Truman bedecked with leis while on a sailing party to Hawaii.    Donor: Werner Stoy.

column1: Mr. and Mrs. Truman Studying a Map
column5: Former President Harry S. Truman (right) and Mrs. Bess Wallace Truman (center) with a gas station owner Carroll Kehne, studying a road map. The Trumans stopped at this Gulf Station at 400 West Patrick Street, Frederick, Maryland, on their road trip. Former President Truman had driven his own car from Missouri to Washington, D.C., to attend to business related to the projected Truman Library.

column1: Former President Harry S. Truman Hands Luggage to Bellhop
column5: Former President Harry S. Truman (center) hands his luggage from the trunk of his car to a bellhop (left) upon his arrival at the Hotel Mayflower in Washington, D.C. He visited Washington to look after business related to his projected Truman Library. All others in this photo are unidentified.

column1: Former President Harry S. Truman Drives into Washington, D.C
column5: Former President Harry S. Truman (right) and former First Lady Bess W. Truman (left) arrive in Washington, D.C. for a visit. Mr. Truman is driving his car. They are in Washington, D.C. to look after business connected to the projected Truman Library.

column1: Harry S. Truman with Konrad Adenauer
column5: Former President Harry S. Truman greeted by Konrad Adenauer, the Federal German Chancellor, in Bonn, during Mr. Truman's visit to the Federal German Capitol.

column1: Harry S. Truman at his desk in the Truman Library
column5: Former President Harry S. Truman working at his desk in the Truman Library.  From Truman Library slide 160.

column1: Truman speaking to a group in the Truman Library auditorium
column5: A group visiting with former President Harry S. Truman in the Truman Library auditorium.  From Truman Library slide number 262.

column1: President Johnson Signing Medicare Bill at Truman Library
column5: President Lyndon B. Johnson (at table, left) and former President Harry S. Truman (at table, right) greet guests in the Harry S. Truman Library auditorium after the signing of the Medicare Bill.  Also pictured: First Lady Lady Bird Johnson (behind President Johnson), Vice-President Hubert Humphrey (behind Truman, left), and Mrs. Bess Truman (behind Truman, right).

column1: Portrait of U. Alexis Johnson
column5: Portrait of U. Alexis Johnson. He was interviewed for an oral history. Mr. Johnson was a United States career Foreign Service officer, from 1935. He later served as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, 1953-58; to Thailand, 1958-61; to Japan, 1966-69; and as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, 1969-73.

column1: Portrait of Laurence E. Bunker
column5: Portrait of Col. Laurence E. Bunker. He was interviewed for an oral history. Mr. Bunker was the Chief Aide to General Douglas MacArthur from April, 1946 to November, 1952.

column1: Thomas Hart Benton sketch, "Mountain Man"
column5: Pencil sketch, "Gridded Study, Mountain Man" drawn by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural for the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The size of the original drawing is 16 7/8 inches by 11 7/8 inches, done at 1/2 inch scale, and is signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Sketch, "Cheyenne Woman's Costume"
column5: Pencil sketch, untitled, drawn by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The drawing shows detail for a Cheyenne Indian woman.  Drawing is signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  Size of original drawing is 11 inches by 8 1/2 inches.  The original drawing is the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Sketch, "Buffalo skull and fox fur"
column5: Pencil sketch drawn by Thomas Hart Benton as a preparatory study for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The drawing is signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original is 17 3/8 inches by 17 1/2 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Benton sketch of hands and head
column5: Pencil sketch on paper drawn by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The sketch is untitled and signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original drawing is 8 1/4 inches by 11 7/8 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.   Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Mural sketch, "Costume Notes"
column5: Pencil sketch drawn by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural for the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The drawing details sketches of a saddle blanket, feathered headdress, earrings, peace pipe and Pawnee hunting moccasin c. 1858.  The drawing is signed "Costume notes/Truman Library/BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original is 9 1/8 inches by 11 7/8 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Benton Mural sketch, "Oxen"
column5: Pencil sketch of a pair of yoked oxen, a single ox, and a yoke, drawn by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The drawing is signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original drawing is 13 7/8 inches by 12 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Benton Mural sketch, "Wagon Wheel"
column5: Inked sketch of wagon wheel done by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The sketch is done in brown, black, and white, and titled "Perspective study of wagon wheel Truman L" in the lower left, and signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original art is 12 1/2 inches by 10 3/4 inches.  The original artwork is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Thomas Hart Benton sketch of back of Cheyenne Indian
column5: Pencil sketch of the back of a Cheyenne Indian drawn by Thomas Hart Benton and used as a study for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The title is in the bottom right, and is signed "BENTON" on the bottom center.  Size of the original drawing is 22 5/8 inches by 14 inches.  This object is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.   Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Thomas Hart Benton sketch, "Costume studies"
column5: Sketch done by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  This pencil sketch on paper is signed in the lower right "BENTON".  The size of the original drawing is 10 15/16 inches by 8 1/4 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Mural sketch, Indian
column5: Pencil sketch of Indian done by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The original art was a gift from Mr. Benton to former President Harry S. Truman.  The drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.

column1: Benton Mural sketch, "Cheyenne Indian head"
column5: Pencil sketch by Thomas Hart Benton done in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The original drawing is untitled and signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  Size of original drawing is 7 7/8 inches by 6 1/4 inches.  The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Preliminary sketch for Benton mural
column5: Preliminary sketch for mural, titled "Truman Mural 1st Preliminary Cartoon 58".  Gouache drawing of entire mural on paper.  Predellas are cut out and adhered to main drawing.  Marked off in pencil in 13/16 inch squares.  Sketch includes plaque on mural over doorway.  Pencil noted in Benton's hand, "Plaque to be eliminated/note model/door/first sketch-Truman mural/[Title]".  Signed bottom right, "BENTON".  The size of the original art is 17 1/2 inches by 27 1/4 inches.  The original art is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Study for Cheyenne sketch by Thomas Hart Benton
column5: A sketch painted by Thomas Hart Benton as a study for his mural for the Harry S. Truman Library.  Original size of sketch is 30 inches by 20 inches and is signed "BENTON" in the lower right corner.  This object is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Sketch, "Chimney Rock, Nebraska"
column5: Pencil sketch done by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural for the lobby for the Harry S. Truman Library.  The title is in the lower right and is signed "BENTON" in the lower right.  The size of the original drawing is 7 5/8 inches by 10 5/8 inches.   The original drawing is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.   Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Thomas Hart Benton sketch, "Pineyan Pine and Juniper K"
column5: Watercolor sketch done by Thomas Hart Benton in preparation for his mural in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library.  The pine is painted in purples and greens, and the juniper is painted in greens with orange and blue.  The size of the original is 20 1/8 inches by 12 3/4 inches.  The original art is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.  Donor of object: Thomas Hart Benton Estate.

column1: Portrait of Elbridge Durbrow
column5: Portrait of Elbridge Durbrow, for Oral History no. 251. Mr. Durbrow was U. S. Foreign Service Officer, 1930-68, including service as liaison secretary at the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, 1944; chief, Eastern European Division, Department of State, 1944-46; counselor of Embassy, Moscow, U.S.S.R., 1946-48; deputy for Foreign Affairs, National War College, 1948-50; chief, Division of Foreign Service Personnel, Department of State, 1950; and minister counselor, American Embassy, Rome, Italy, 1952-54. Subsequently, served as U. S. Ambassador to Vietnam, 1957-61, and as alternate U. S. permanent representative on the North Atlantic Council, 1961-67.

column1: Portrait of Robert L. Sweeny, a friend of Harry S. Truman
column5: Portrait of Robert L. Sweeny, a friend of Harry S. Truman, and the first Black supervisor in the Kansas City, Missouri Post Office, 1948.  Donor:  Robert L. Sweeney

column1: View of Broken Exhibit Case Where Swords Were Stolen from Truman Library
column5: More distance view of the broken glass in the lobby exhibit case where swords were stolen during a break-in at the Harry S. Truman Library. The swords were gifts from King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317). This photo is in a contact sheet book and is from an original 2x2 negative.

column1: Broken Exhibit Case for Stolen Swords at Truman Library
column5: A view of the broken glass in the lobby exhibit case where swords and daggers were stolen in a break-in at the Harry S. Truman Library. The swords and daggers were gifts of King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317). This photo is in a contact sheet book and is from an original 2x2 negative.

column1: Photo of Inspection of Broken Case After Theft of Truman Library Swords and Daggers
column5: Photo of unidentified security man inspecting the break-in area of the Harry S. Truman Library lobby where swords and daggers were stolen. The swords were gifts of King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317.) This photo is in a contact sheet book, and from an original 2x2 inch negative.

column1: Broken Sword Exhibit Case After Theft of Truman Library Swords
column5: Broken exhibit case in the lobby of the Harry S. Truman Library where swords and daggers were stolen in a break-in. The swords and daggers were the gift of King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317.) This photo is in a contact sheet book and is from the Library's original 2x2 negative.

column1: Photo of Hall Doors at Truman Library Tampered With During Theft of Swords
column5: Photo of the hall doors at the Harry S. Truman Library that thieves attempted to chain during the break-in and theft of swords and daggers in the lobby exhibit. The swords were gifts from King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317). This photo is in a contact sheet book and is from an original 35mm negative.

column1: Broken Exhibit Case for Swords that were Stolen from Truman Library
column5: Photo of an exhibit case with broken glass from which swords and daggers were stolen during a break-in at the Harry S. Truman Library. The swords and daggers were gifts from King Ibn Saud and Crown Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. (See also photos 77-3405 and 72-3317). This photo is in a contact sheet book and from a 2x2 original negative.
